The Resinbond K-250 process takes place in a single vessel. The vessel is a 9100 gallon stainless steel batch reactor. This process is regulated due to two chemicals. The first chemical being Formaldehyde 50% solution and second chemical being Acetone. The preventive safeguard systems in place for this process are as follows:

- A Process Hazard Analysis(PHA) was conducted on August 20, 2013

- The batch reactor R-107 has a pressure relief device (or pressure safety valve) installed

- All fixtures in and around the R-107 reactor area are intrinsically safe / explosion proof

- Reactor R-107 is a stainless steel jacketed vessel that will allow for rapid cooling to assist with the inhibition of a runaway reaction

Written Safety and Health Policy

Dystar has a written safety and health policy that clearly states the company's commitment to effective safety and health management and to providing a safe and healthy working environment. .  Additionally, Dystar has a formal written Process Safety Management Program that begins with the General Safety Statement regarding PSM / RMP chemicals

Accessibility

Dystar has an open door policy for reporting and (or) discussing EH&S related issues and (or) concerns. 

Program Evaluation

Dystar management ensures a sound EH&S program is in place and working properly by contracting with a third party EH&S consultant. The third party EH&S consultant performs periodic audits / assessments to ensure effectiveness of EH&S programs as they apply.

Recognition of Employee Safety and Health Efforts

Dystar addresses employee safety and health efforts at a minimum of once a year during the employee's annual performance review. Additionally, supervisors are encouraged to recognize and praise employees for following specific safety and health work practices. 

Communication

Dystar's approach to managing safety and health includes verbal and written communication as a two-way  process between employer and employees.  Dystar keeps employees informed and invites feedback and suggestions.











 

Dystar's regulated substances 



Dystar L.P. located at 209 Watling Industrial Drive in Reidsville; North Carolina is a chemical

manufacturing facility. Dystar manufactures auxiliary chemicals for the textile industry and the leather industry as well as custom chemical manufacturing.



Dystar's manufacturing plant operates batch reactors that synthe chemicals to support the textile and leather industry. Dystar is subject to the requirements of RMP due to the Resinbond K-250 process. This process is carried out as follows:



Resinbond K-250

1.    A load of Formaldehyde 50% solution is brought onsite via over-the-road cargo tanker (MC-307/DOT-407)

2.    The amount of Formaldehyde varies based on supplier but the average poundage received onsite is 45,000lbs

3.    The entire cargo tanker of Formaldehyde 50% solution is offloaded into a reactor (a large sealable mixing vessel) utilizing vacuum as the offloading method as opposed to pumping or pressurizing.

4.    Through a formula (or batch recipe) procedure, additional chemicals are added in a designated sequence.

5.    Acetone in excess of 10,000lbs is added as part of the process. The acetone is charged into the reactor utilizing a vacuum process the same as Formaldehyde. The acetone is transferred from a storage tank via jumper hose that is not permanently connected. For safety purposes, the headspace in the acetone storage tank is blanketed with Nitrogen thus removing all oxygen and preventing possibility of ignition

6.    Additional constituents are added per operating procedures. No additional constituents fall under the RMP requirements.

7.    The end product is a non DOT regulated intermediate for paper adhesive











General accidental release prevention program and chemical-specific prevention steps



Due to the aforementioned covered process, Dystar complies with EPA 40 CFR part 68 and 29 CFR 1910.119. Our Process Safety Management (PSM) enables our facility to prevent the occurrence, and minimize the consequences, of significant releases of toxic substances as well as fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall, th

e PSM prevents accidental fatalities, injuries and illnesses and avoids physical property damage.

The "process" part of the Process Management Program is any activity involving a highly hazardous chemical including any use, storage, manufacturing, handling, or the on-site movement of such chemicals, or combination of these activities. Any group of vessels that are interconnected and separate vessels that are located such that a highly hazardous chemical could be involved in a potential release shall be considered a single process.

Our PSM / RMP prevents accidents because it focuses on the rules, procedures, and practices that govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are detailed and improved as necessary. They are also communicated to and accepted by all persons at the facility.

At the same time, our PSM / RMP covers not only highly hazardous chemicals, but also those that may be harmless in terms of flammability, explosiveness, or toxicity, but, when mixed with another substance, can produce a highly hazardous substance or situation. The accidental mixing of some reactive chemicals can cause explosions or the release of toxic vapors - situations that are clearly a threat to the life and health of workers at the site.

Like all PSM / RMP written programs, Dystar's contains at a minimum the following major elements:

?    Purpose statement, 

?    Employee participation plan, 

?    Process safety information, 

?    Process hazard analysis records, 

?    Operating procedures, 

?    Training, 

?    Contracting, 

?    Process equipment integrity maintenance procedures, 

?    Non-routine work, 

?    Management of change procedures, 

?    Incident investigation reports, 

?    Compliance audit reports, and 

?    Emergency Action Plan



Additional Prevention Program Practices

 

?    A formal Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) is performed using Hazard Review Leader software and a diverse team of subject matter experts

?    Corrective action is taken as needed based on r

esults from PHA

?    Site specific and process specific training is performed for all affected employees









Five-year accident history



This is a first time RMP submittal for this process and the first time Dystar LP has met the RMP covered process submission requirements. Any accidents occurring in the future will be investigated, documented, and followed up with for root cause determination and initiation of preventive measures. This information will be included in the five-year revalidation process.

 



Emergency Response Program



Dystar has a comprehensive Integrated Contingency Plan (ICP). This emergency plan addresses all elements of the OSHA mandated Emergency Action Plan (EAP), Fire Prevention Plan (FPP), and the Resource Conservation recovery Act (RCRA) Contingency Plan. This plan meets and (or) exceeds the requirements of emergency action for PSM / RMP covered processes. The elements of the plan are as follows:



Emergency Action Job Descriptions - Identifies key personnel and their respective roles during and emergency situation



Procedures for Emergency Notification - Identifies who needs to be notified during an emergency and includes their updated contact information



Procedures for Chemical Emergency - Includes procedures to be followed in the event of a chemical emergency situation

 

Procedures for Fire Emergency - Includes procedures to be followed in the event of a fire related emergency situation



Procedures for Emergency Response - Describes Dystar's policy and procedures for actual response to an emergency situation including limitations





Procedures for Evacuation / Accountability - Includes procedures for evacuation of the facility due to an emergency situation and includes accountability of personnel. Also, this section includes information regarding audible / visual warning systems in the event of an emergency



Procedures for Other Emergencies - Addresses emergency action for other emergency situations



Incident Inv

estigation - Indicates Dystar's policy and process for conducting an investigation of an emergency including a root cause and prevention recommendations





Additional Elements of Dystar's Response Program:



?    Dystar has mailed a copy of the ICP to all public safety partners and requested acknowledgement. Most public safety partners responded and a letter of acknowledgement is on file for those that did respond.

?    Dystar employees have been trained on the PSM / RMP covered process and the respective elements

?    Dystar is an active member of the Rockingham County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC)

?    Plant evacuation drill are conducted periodically

?    Public notification (if necessary) will be handled by Rockingham County Emergency services. Most likely the form of Public notification will be the reverse 911 system in conjunction with other methods as determined by the local response agencies.







Planned changes to improve safety



Dystar management as previously mentioned is committed to employee safety as well as the community. Through a formal Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) minor action items were identified for review and possible corrective action. Each action item was assigned to a responsible individual(s).  



Dystar committed to continuous improvement especially as it relates to EH&S systems and processes.
